subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue(true)
msgSnippet: ... I tend to .... try { articleProvider.findArticleById( foobar ); fail( NoObjectFoundException not thrown ); catch(NoObjectFoundException e) { // Sometimes
messageBody:
haefeleuser wrote:

>Someone in our team writes his tests like this:
>
>try
>{
> articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
>}
>catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
>{
> assertTrue(true);
>}
>
>He says the does it because otherwise Checkstyle would complain about
>the empty catch block.
>
>I do it in this manner:
>
>try
>{
> articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");
>}
>catch(NoObjectFoundException e)
>{
> // Its okay since we expect it.
>}
>
>
>

I tend to ....


try {

articleProvider.findArticleById("foobar");

fail("NoObjectFoundException not thrown");

catch(NoObjectFoundException e) {
// Sometimes its good to check the contents of the exception
// to check that its been thrown because of what we expected
//and not through some other means.
assertEquals("right exception, but wrong ID", "foobar", e.getID());
}
